sections.text: Camila Vega: Hi Diego, Camila Vega here—thanks for taking a few minutes. I’ll keep this brief. I’m calling because we work with teams that are trying to get really clear on who their best customers are and stop wasting time on “maybe” leads. Does that hit anything you’re dealing with at Birch & Beam Architects?
Diego Arnold: Hey Camila. We’re in the middle of a few initiatives, but sure—what are you talking about specifically?

Camila Vega: Totally. The product is called Customer_Analyzer. It pulls together the signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding notes, project outcomes, support or change-order requests, even interview notes—and turns them into a simple fit score by account and by segment. The goal is to help you define an ICP you can actually trust, so marketing and sales aren’t guessing.
Diego Arnold: We’re not a SaaS company. We’re an architecture firm. Not sure how relevant an “ICP” tool is for us.

Camila Vega: Fair question. When we say ICP, we mean “best-fit client profile.” In your case it could be things like project type, client size, timeline realism, decision process, budget reliability, revision load—whatever predicts profitable projects and smoother delivery. Customer_Analyzer’s fit estimation feature gives you a 0–100 fit score and a driver breakdown—so you can see why a client is high fit or low fit and compare segments like commercial developers vs. institutional clients.
Diego Arnold: We already have a general sense of what good clients look like. It’s not super scientific, but we know.

Camila Vega: That makes sense—and honestly most teams do. Where we see Customer_Analyzer help is when the “general sense” breaks down as you grow, add new services, or pursue new verticals. For example, if you’re considering scaling outbound or paid acquisition, it validates which segment actually retains well and expands—rather than just “closes.” Then the fit estimation highlights the drivers: time-to-value, support burden, revision cycles, payment issues—so you can operationalize it.
Diego Arnold: We don’t do paid acquisition, and we’re not really scaling the way a startup is. We’re mostly referral-driven.

Camila Vega: Got it—so referrals are primary. Even then, the same problem can show up as inconsistent project profitability or teams getting stretched thin because the wrong work sneaks in. The other output is positioning recommendations—basically messaging guidance based on what high-fit clients value and what objections come up. That can show up on your website, proposals, or qualification scripts.
Diego Arnold: We just refreshed our website and proposal templates. And messaging isn’t our main pain right now.

Camila Vega: Understood. Let me ask one quick diagnostic—are you seeing any patterns in projects that become time sinks? Like certain client types that create lots of scope churn, change orders, or delays?
Diego Arnold: Sure, some clients are harder than others. But it’s not something we’re going to buy software for. We handle it in process.

Camila Vega: That’s fair. The reason I ask is the fit estimation can quantify those patterns from your existing data—say, which attributes correlate with smoother delivery and repeat work. Even a lightweight setup can show, “These 3 drivers predict the projects that renew or expand,” versus the ones that churn you out with headaches.
Diego Arnold: I’m also thinking about the effort. We don’t have a bunch of clean data lying around, and I don’t have time to instrument everything.

Camila Vega: Totally hear you. We don’t require heavy instrumentation to start. Many teams begin with what they already have: CRM fields, a few tags on project type, basic timeline/budget outcomes, maybe a short survey. Then Customer_Analyzer produces segment comparisons and a recommended best-fit profile based on observed outcomes. But if data isn’t centralized, it can feel like work up front.
Diego Arnold: Yeah. And honestly, we’re trying to reduce tools, not add another dashboard.

Camila Vega: Makes sense. If we kept this to a single outcome—like “identify the top 2 client segments to prioritize and a short qualification checklist”—would that be worth a 30-minute deeper look? I can show exactly how the fit score and driver breakdown works with a sample dataset.
Diego Arnold: I don’t think so. We’ve got internal planning for the next couple weeks, and this doesn’t feel like a priority.

Camila Vega: No problem. Before I let you go, is there someone else on your side who owns pipeline quality or client selection—maybe whoever runs business development or operations—who would be a better fit for this conversation?
Diego Arnold: Not really. We’re pretty small, and those decisions are shared. If it becomes a pain later, we’ll revisit, but right now we’re set.

Camila Vega: Understood. Last thing—would it be okay if I sent a one-pager that summarizes the fit estimation output and how it’s used to validate an ideal client profile? If it resonates later, you can forward it internally.
Diego Arnold: Sure, you can send something. But I can’t promise I’ll look at it soon.
Camila Vega: That’s completely fine. What’s the best email for you?
Diego Arnold: Use diego@birchbeam.com.

Camila Vega: Perfect. I’ll send a short overview and a couple example screenshots of the fit score and segment comparison. If in a quarter you’re revisiting what work to pursue—or noticing certain client types dragging margins—we can pick it back up. Thanks again for your time, Diego.
Diego Arnold: Thanks, Camila. Take care.
